comments.text: copied from another website
comments.author: Oggab0gga

comments.text:
+94Newbie No. Humans breathe more than fish.

The average human breathes about 500mls of air per breath as their standard 
tidal volume
Of that 500 mls, 21% is oxygen going in, and 16% is oxygen coming out, 
meaning that we strip about 5% of the volume of every breath as pure 
oxygen, or about 25mls (0.025 liters)
Using Avagadro’s Law (1 mole of any gas occupies 22.4 liters) we see:
V1/n1 = V2/n2 –> 22.4L/1mol = 0.025L/Xmol –> X = 0.00111mol.  Each breath 
consumes 0.00111 moles of oxygen gas
From the molar weight of di-molecular oxygen gas (16g x 2 = 32g/mol), we 
can calculate that each breath is:
32g * 0.00111mol = 0.03552g of oxygen, or 35.52 milligrams (mg)
Now, well-oxygenated surface ocean waters (on Earth of course, I have no 
idea about Naboo) contain about 6mg/L of oxygen.
So, to supply one breath’s worth of oxygen, the Triton would need to filter 
35.52mg/6mgL = 5.92L of water.  Let’s call it 6L for convenience.  And it 
would need to do so with 100% extraction efficiency, which is not realistic 
under any diffusion or adsorption scenario, but let’s give Mr Yeon the 
benefit of the doubt.
The average person breathes around 15 times per minute at rest.  Lets 
assume we’re diving in a restful fashion, and not chasing Gungans into the 
underwaterways to escape Colo Clawfish
Therefore, to supply you with oxygen at normal resting breathing rates, the 
Triton would need to filter 15 x 6L = 90L per minute, or about 24 gallons. 
 For scale, 25 gallons a minute is about as much as a 1/4 horsepower sump 
pump pushes out, depending on static head. Without any kind of pump in the 
Triton to move water through the device, it relies on swimming (and 
presumably breathe suction?) to create the flow of water.  There’s too many 
variables in that, but let’s just say you’d certainly have to swim so fast 
to supply the needs of 15bpm that you wouldn’t be breathing 15bpm anymore.
comments.author: Oggab0gga

comments.text:
If that much water would be needed for a little bit of oxigen there wouldnt 
be any fish in the ocean. doesnt mean that this triton thing works, but its 
not impossible. the amount of oxigen you get depends, on a number of 
things, the ability of the used membrane to extract oxigen, the surface 
area of it and the amount of water passing over it. the gills of fish are 
actually not all that good in extracting oxigen per square meter, but the 
surface area of them is enourmous.

comments.text:
LeetKey is a handy little add-on which saves you a LOT of work to decrypt 
binary, hex, morse, Rot13 and others. Further it allows you  encrypt your 
Text with AES and DES so that only persons with the right key can read it. 
Try to solve this:
qUMyIEYBITAhITAhLXPcf4sIgz6cBl8lGdH0mlUtBjmwD9UBPyq9pg==
You won't be able to decrypt it without the password which is "leetkey" in 
this case.
I really admire your hard work and knowledge because I wouldn't have even 
thought about doing that manually, although I know binary and hex! Call me 
a cheater but I don't have the time doing that manually :D

comments.author: Lincoln were

comments.text:
+Frostbite1003 Ooh, a challenge!

I'm going to do this manually. No outside references. I'm going to explain 
it along the way.

First off, I can see a very long series of 30's and 31's, followed by an 
occasional 20 every 8 iterations. This tells me that these are all 
hexadecimal representations of 0, 1, and " ", respectively.

So I plugged it into vim and issued a few regexes to convert it into 
something easier to work with. I started with

30 30 31 31 30 31 30 30 20 30 31 31 30 30 30 31 31 20 30 30 31 30 30 30 30 
30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 31 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 30 31 20 30 30 31 30 30 
30 30 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 31 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 30 31 20 30 30 31 
30 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 31 31 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 30 30 20 30 
30 31 30 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 30 30 20 30 31 31 30 30 30 31 30 
20 30 30 31 30 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 31 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 
30 31 20 30 30 31 30 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 31 31 20 30 30 31 31 
31 30 30 31 20 30 30 31 30 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 30 31 30 20 30 30 
31 31 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 30 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 31 30 20 
30 30 31 31 30 31 31 30 20 30 30 31 30 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 31 
31 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 30 30 20 30 30 31 30 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 
31 31 31 20 30 30 31 31 30 31 31 31 20 30 30 31 30 30 30 30 30 20 30 30 31 
31 30 30 31 30 20 30 30 31 31 30 30 30 31 20 30 30 31 30 30 30 30 30 20﻿
<feff>


The <feff> is a weird control character that YouTube inserted, recognized 
by vim.

And after using the following regexes

:1s/3//g
--removes all 3's from 30's and 31's
:1s/20/^M/g
--turns all "spaces" into newlines
:$d
--deletes the last line, and thus the <feff>
:%s/ //g
--deletes all spaces
:%s/\(....\)/\1 /
--inserts a space after the first four letters of each line

ended up with:

0011 0100
0110 0011
0010 0000
0011 0110
0011 0101
0010 0000
0011 0110
0011 0101
0010 0000
0011 0111
0011 0100
0010 0000
0011 0100
0110 0010
0010 0000
0011 0110
0011 0101
0010 0000
0011 0111
0011 1001
0010 0000
0011 0010
0011 0000
0010 0000
0011 0110
0011 0110
0010 0000
0011 0111
0011 0100
0010 0000
0011 0111
0011 0111
0010 0000
0011 0010
0011 0001
0010 0000

Notes:

^M is vim's representation of the carriage return character, or ASCII #13 
(or 0D). It is inserted into a command line via Ctrl-V, followed by Ctrl-M 
(or Ctrl-V, Ctrl-Enter)

\(pattern\) can be re-used in a replace as \1, so s/\(foo\)/\1!!!/ would 
turn "foo" into "foo!!!"

Now that I have this, I can start turning each binary octet into their 
hexadecimal couplet counterparts:

:%s/0000/0/g
:%s/0001/1/g
:%s/0010/2/g
:%s/0011/3/g
:%s/0100/4/g
:%s/0101/5/g
:%s/0110/6/g
:%s/0111/7/g
:%s/1001/9/g
--basic stuff , just replacing each binary number with their hex 
counterparts
:%s/ //
--remove all spaces

I get this:

34 
63 
20 
36 
35 
20 
36 
35 
20 
37 
34 
20 
34 
62 
20 
36 
35 
20 
37 
39 
20 
32 
30 
20 
36 
36 
20 
37 
34 
20 
37 
37 
20 
32 
31 
20 

Then more replacing. This is where the unicode table at unicode-table.com 
comes in handy, but I've become so familiar with ASCII that I usually can 
do it off the top of my head.

:%s/20/ /
:%s/62/b/
:%s/63/c/
:%s/3//

And then I join each group manually
Shift-J to join
dd to delete line
:%s/ //
--to delete all spaces
:%s/$/ /
--to insert spaces at the the ends

4c 
65 
65 
74 
4b 
65 
79 
20 
66 
74 
77 
21 

And then I convert once more (this is where I drew up a quick unicode table)

:%s/4c/L/
:%s/65/e/
:%s/74/t/
:%s/4b/K/

At this point, I stop seeing recurring numbers, so I just manually go in an 
swap each one out.

And then I hit `gg` to go to the first line, and hold J (shift+J, for join) 
until there's only one line, then clean up a little.

I get this: "LeetKey Ftw!"

And here's the table I drew up for reference at the last stage:  
http://pastebin.com/KniM3TV6

So...what's LeetKey?

comments.author: cryhvc

comments.text:
my thoughts on what the mouthpiece would need.

Here is what most of us humans breath on a daily basis:
78.04% nitrogen
21% oxygen
0.96% argon

I may have exaggerated about 100% oxygen killing you but at high pressure ( 
i.e in the ocean) there can be very severe consequences, including death. 
Time is obviously a factor, its not like one puff and instant death, but 
not something you want to be breathing for and extended period of time. 
That being said the air that divers breath is usually oxygen or helium rich 
(usually helium). 

Now that being said astronauts in very little/ no pressure can breath in 
100% oxygen for a week or two with no real side effects.
comments.author: Oblivionking13x

comments.text:
+Richard Alexander
you speak bullshit, the "secret" is in the submarines and has nothing to do 
with water temp... nuclear subs these days can stay submerged for months on 
end without having to re-surfarce for oxygen or fuel (since its nuclear 
powered) how ever it does re-surface for food reasons...
they get their oxygen with a machine that turns water into oxygen, which is

comments.author: Indi rulz

comments.text:
+khangas wolf That isn't true. The oxygen content of the water is not 
directly related to the oxygen content of the air. The oxygen content of 
water depends a lot on the water's temperature. No matter how much oxygen 
air has in it, hot water cannot hold dissolve oxygen, at least not very 
much. 

Edit: I don't know how that second sentence got corrupted, but I've edited, 
now.
comments.author: Richard Alexander

comments.text:
if there is no oxygen in the water, it doesn't matter, cos that would mean 
there is no oxygen in the air. so you're dead ether way.
comments.author: Khangas Oozaki - DARKEYEgamez

comments.text:
+punji73 What if there is no oxygen dissolved in the water? This device 
does not break down the oxygen in the chemical bond; it is supposed to 
filter out the dissolved oxygen. So, it's performance depends on how much 
oxygen is dissolved in the water. As it happens, water cannot hold enough 
dissolved oxygen to support normal human respiration from such a small 
device. It needs to be much larger.
comments.author: Richard Alexander

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Avagantamos 
Originally I was going to say this as a joke, but upon reading the whole 
post, I am now serious about this.
You just described Mega Man (sorta)
Step 1: Human creates intelligent robots (Shortly before Mega Man 1)
Step 2: Robots become equal with humans (Mega Man classic series)
Step 3: Robots naturally replace humans in all ways (Mega Man X, Zero, ZX)
Step 4: Robots become what used to be humanity (Mega Man Legends)
comments.author: Blade Avuari

comments.text:
+Kyle Duncan It's not just the fear of them overcoming us. Its the fear 
that humanity has created another similar form of us, to include in our day 
to day lives. We form their faces like us, and use them to help us with day 
to day tasks, to create an illusion of empathy and technological 
companionship. Many believe that a humans brain is computational, and this 
belief causes the ambition to create robots that can be sentient. The 
problem with this awe inspiring advantage that humans may or may not create 
is either going to be the abuse control we'll have on the robots or a shift 
in what we'd call real companionship. Like most technology nowadays, we 
have already dissuaded from genuine congregation to a form of social 
interaction that the internet easily creates for us. Though us individuals 
are fully in control of these creations, as a society, we fail to control 
anything. If robots are compatible enough to be scattered throughout the 
social interaction of humans, we will no longer be using them to our own 
disabilities, rather they will have us at a surprise to help us when they 
seek fit. That's the whole point of social interaction, to have s society 
that is run with the help of robots. Not everyone will understand this and 
not everyone will see a problem with it. With whomever is in charge of that 
robot, or those robots, they are certainly aiming to change society in how 
we think and what we can do for ourselves. To think that we can replace any 
human with a programmed robot that has no understanding or human-like 
precision is sickening. We need other humans, to be loved and nurtured. If 
we ever do create the shitty robots that iRobot had before the nice looking 
white ones, it is because we have seemingly destroyed all human value and 
only cared about how society functions and works. Humanity then becomes a 
system. You may say that this is freedom, that we can do more of what we 
want because the robots are doing our job for us. But you are missing the 
point, that if we ever did create robots of that capability, we would no 
longer seek value in what we'd call a natural meditation, for lack of a 
better word. But, society is already a system, you may ask. That is true, 
however we ourselves make the decision with the use of human-like emotion, 
eons away from what any robot would be able to have.
comments.author: Avagantamos

comments.text:
+Avagantamos They wouldn't be bad, it's like you, are you bad because you 
have free will? The biggest reason why robots will never become fully 
sentient and have free will is because of one huge problem, we can not 
program free will or emotions, can can program a robot to either follow or 
disobey orders, but that isn't free will. We can program a robot to show 
sadness in a situation, but that isn't emotions. Until we are able to 
program emotions and free will, robots will never overthrow us or go rogue 
like in I Robot.
comments.author: Sokino Sokino

comments.text:
+brent mckibben They would definitely be bad. Think about it, giving a

like fucking terminator.

comments.author: Radigan Conagher

comments.text:
Art terminology isn't physics terminology. In art class if we mix all the 
paints we get a murky colour. In physics we get white.

In fact, that is also how computers demonstrate their colours. RGB is split 
into three values between 0 and 255. If all values are 255, the final 
output is white.

How colour is determined in physics or computer science is not the same as 
how colour is determined with crayons or paint.

Don't talk down to people if that is how you choose to perceive the world.
comments.author: The Anathema

comments.author: Marco Daniel

captions.text:
Researchers have discovered how to reuse paper
by creating a printer that uses water instead
of ink so the print fades within a day.

And Korea is planning to build a new 1.23
billion dollar city that will include a theme
park and hotels.... FOR ROBOTS.
Vsauce! Kevin here - this is Mind Blow.

Scientists at the Albert Einstein college
of Medicine were able to see how the brain

makes memories using advanced imaging techniques
by tagging memory molecules in a mouse model
with fluorescent tags.

Eyes On glasses let you see through skin to
get to veins. Evena Medical created the glasses

that work by pulsing four different kinds
of light into the skin and then combining

it into a single composite image. This gives
healthcare workers a clear, real time, anatomically

correct image of the veins beneath the skin
to reduce issues like multiple needle sticks.

The AKA24 is a future driving concept featuring
a magnetic road you drive sideways on next

to a traditional road.  Designed by Chuang
Dong and winner of the Michelin Design Challenge

drivers can choose to stop controlling their
vehicle and instead ride the maglev-like railroad

system. Once connected to the railway the
car is flipped on its side into the undriven

position where the driver would rotate to
stay upright.

This robotic ankle mimics the muscles, tendons
and ligaments of the lower leg. A collaboration

between Harvard University, USC, MIT, and
BioSensics have developed an orthotic device

to help those with ankle and foot injuries.
It uses pneumatic artificial muscles and soft

materials that are able to act like real muscles
by expanding and contracting but work is still
being done to make it wearable for patients.

Peanut allergies have been essentially cured
in 9 out of 10 kids with a new treatment that

gradually escalates the amount of peanut protein
the body can handle.

Glyph is a mobile personal theater. The virtual
retinal display uses one million micromirrors

in each eyepiece and projects images directly
onto your retina creating super sharp imagery.

Users can connect to their personal content
library or stream movies from a smartphone,

and even use it for gaming. It can also be
used as an audio device and worn like headphones

and all you have to do is pull the visor down
over your eyes to start the visual display.

Researchers at MIT have created a wearable
book that makes the reader feel the same sensations

that the characters in the book are feeling.
It uses 150 LED lights and a series on sensors

attached to a vest worn by the reader. During
scary parts the vest contracts around the

chest and waist, vibrations occur during exciting
passages to raise the heart rate, and somber
moments trigger soft dark lights.

This new device is designed to harvest energy
from your organs. The piezoelectric device

has been created to constantly recharge pacemakers
and other implanted devices. It's sewn directly

onto the heart, lungs, or diaphragm because
those organs are in constant motion. The device

has nanoribbons made of lead zirconate titanate
which bend slightly as the organs move creating

small amounts of energy to power the implanted
device.

Triton is an oxygen respirator concept that
uses an artificial gill model. It extracts

oxygen through a filter in the form of fine
threads with holes smaller than water molecules.

Just by simply biting on it, the user is able
to breath for long periods of time underwater

just as if they were on land removing the
need to learn how to use complicated scuba
equipment.

Vigo can gauge your energy level and tell
you when to nap. The wearable device monitors

your alertness throughout the day by tracking
patterns in blinks and your body's movements

so that it knows you're drowsy before you
do. And it can also make suggestions on how

to change your routine to be the most efficient
based on your average level of alertness over
the course of a day.

Finally, Antimedia created a reel of footage
using Cinedrones - an aerial camera system.

I'm gonna leave you with Rynocycle an electric
unicycle - and as always - thanks for watching!

title: This Is What Memories Look Like -- Mind Blow #78
